Description: Faience griffin's head and neck, broken off at bottom of neck just below a ridge which indicates that it was a protome, with attachment (now lost) to another object.There is a small original depression in the centre of the base. It is badly broken, missing ears and central knob which would originally have risen on top of head, and muzzle. A distinctive feature is the 'beard' which runs right round under chin to front of neck. It is made of fine, green glazed composition, now mottled brown, which recalls the close texture of Saite apple green faience. Top of head, horns and snout broken away. Eyes marked by incised lines.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Glazing MSS p.18 Late Period? This is a griffin head, with horns, of Persian date. See also additional references in comment on BM 1886,0401.1401.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FD.04)
